post_info.post_title: What Props up the Dollar?  Why does it have Value?

A lot of the strength of the dollar is propped up by the requirement by the IMF and World Bank that currency reserves are held in dollars, as I understand it.

Yeah oil's a big one, pretty much every oil producing country asks for payment in $US.
 
 
Currently the U.S. is an import country, even though the size and natural resources are hardly an issue.

 
 In a free market, when a nation imports more than it exports, this results in a declining value of money in that nation, which tends to resolve the balance of payments. (As their money becomes worth less internationally, they have a reduced incentive to import, and the people of other nations have an increased incentive to purchase their exports).
 
 So we could predict that the $US should decline, however the actions of other national governments around the world are at present preventing that, for various reasons. As is the use of the $US as a proxy-currency around the world where inflation is rampant locally, which somewhat reinforces the value of it, but would never alone sustain it without the continued action of eg China's central banks. This situation won't hold forever though. So it's a good long run bet, but it's hard to say when exactly it will drop sufficiently that the balance of payments is restored.
 
 I also disagree with the idea that "Japan will always be a slave to its resource needs.", the resources present within a nation need not constrain the prosperity of the people living there, so long as international trade barriers do not restrict their ability to purchase those goods internationally. In fact, national boundaries are meaningless under such circumstances, the only real burden people living in such places must bear is the cost of transportation.

I am interested in knowing the effect the Middle Eastern peace deal had on the dollar. Could it be that Jimmy Carter's peace deal with Israel and Egypt had a massive impact on the use of the dollar through out the Middle East?  So I would find it difficult to believe that the result of this activity has been positive for any but a few, regardless of its direct effects on the dollar's value.
 
 And of course, once such arrangements end, as they inevitably will, they will end in a crisis situation as the malinvestments it has engendered are liquidated. Your guess is as good as mine as to how that will play out, but you can guarantee it won't be pretty.
